alert.note: Alert for Central Interior (Alaska) Issued by the National Weather Service

info.headline: Flood Advisory issued May 21 at 4:41PM AKDT by NWS Fairbanks
info.description: ...FLOOD ADVISORY FOR AN ICE JAM REMAINS IN EFFECT UNTIL 1215 PM AKDT MONDAY... * WHAT...Flooding caused by an ice jam continues. * WHERE...Yukon River between Tanana and the Nowitna River. * WHEN...Until 1215 PM AKDT Monday. * IMPACTS...Minor flooding in low-lying areas along the Yukon River between Tanana and Nowitna River is occuring, with and minor flooding of the lower Nowitna River. Water levels are now falling slowly. Flooding of low lying roads in Tanana is occuring and will continue for the next several days. Water levels at Tanana have fallen about 1 foot today, and will fall slowly over the next several days. Some areas of ponded water will have water remain for a number of days. Locations that have ice onshore will have that ice remain for days until it melts. * ADDITIONAL DETAILS... - At 424 PM AKDT Sunday,The ice jam near the Kokrines Bible Camp broke early Sunday morning and water levels are dropping. Water levels at the Bible Camp have dropped over 3 feet today, and water levels at Tanana have dropped about 1 foot today. Flood water remains in low lying areas along the Yukon River upstream as far as Tanana and in the lower part of the Nowitna River. Water will slowly drain back into the river over the next several days.. Some poorly drained areas will keep water for many days. Ice that is up on shore will remain for many days until it melts. - - For Tanana: At 12:00pm Sunday the stage was 86.22 feet. Flood Stage is 86.0 feet. - http://www.weather.gov/safety/flood - If you live near or along the Yukon River between the Nowitna River and Tanana, or along the lower Nowitna River, take action to protect yourself from flooding. Water may remain high in poorly drained areas many days.
info.instruction: People along the Yukon River between Tanana and the Nowitna River should be aware that flooding is occuring in low lying areas. Water levels are now falling slowly.
